intro: Agalinis purpurea var. purpurea, commonly known as the purplestem false foxglove, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as roadsides and sandy soils. The plant features slender, erect stems and produces clusters of tubular, purple to pink flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. It is often found in disturbed areas and is adapted to thrive in dry, well-drained conditions.
